results.title: ‘I Don’t Take a Single Second for Granted’: Asian and Asian American Nominees on the Oscars
results.abstract: It was a record year for actors, but directors, musicians and other artists of Asian descent are also up for statuettes. We asked many of the contenders to reflect on their work.
results.byline: By Robert Ito and Justin J Wee

multimedia.caption: Hong Chau is nominated for best supporting actress for her role as Liz, the stern but kind friend of an obese teacher in “The Whale.”

results.title: Asian Actors Have Been Underrepresented at the Oscars For Decades. Here’s the History.
results.abstract: A record number of actors of Asian ancestry were recognized with Oscar nominations this year, led by Michelle Yeoh of “Everything Everywhere All at Once.” Historically, Asian stars have rarely been part of the Academy Awards.

multimedia.copyright: Clockwise from top left: Columbia Pictures; David Bornfriend/A24; David James/Warner Bros.; A24

results.title: Brendan Fraser Wants to Be Worthy of His Comeback
results.abstract: “I’m aware of where I was, where I went and where I am now,” says the actor, who is nominated for an Oscar for his remarkable comeback in “The Whale.”

results.title: SAG Awards 2023: ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once’ and Michelle Yeoh Win Big
results.abstract: The film took the top prize, as well as lead actress and two supporting trophies. “Abbott Elementary” and “The White Lotus” were named the top TV shows.

results.title: Walter Mirisch, Pioneering Producer of Canonical Films, Dies at 101
results.abstract: Admired for his creative instincts, he oversaw films that won 28 Oscars, including “West Side Story,” “The Apartment” and “In the Heat of the Night.”
des_facet: In the Heat of the Night (Movie)
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: The film producer Walter Mirisch in 1975 in Los Angeles. The Mirisch Company, which he and two brothers founded in 1957, grew to be an industry powerhouse.
The film producer Walter Mirisch in 1975 in Los Angeles. The Mirisch Company, which he and two brothers founded in 1957, grew to be an industry powerhouse.
The film producer Walter Mirisch in 1975 in Los Angeles. The Mirisch Company, which he and two brothers founded in 1957, grew to be an industry powerhouse.

results.title: A Polarizing French Philosopher Chooses War Zones Over Salons
results.abstract: In a new film, “Slava Ukraini,” the writer and filmmaker Bernard-Henri Lévy warns of a heavy price if the West fails to defeat Putin in Ukraine.

multimedia.caption: Lévy is a deeply polarizing character, mocked by some critics as a dilettante or sound bite philosopher. He appears aloof from the criticism, viewing his work as a higher calling.
multimedia.copyright: Clement Pascal for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Lévy is a deeply polarizing character, mocked by some critics as a dilettante or sound bite philosopher. He appears aloof from the criticism, viewing his work as a higher calling.

results.abstract: The prize is a strong indicator of what will win best picture at the Oscars. The film already won the Directors Guild Award.

results.abstract: The violence of Mexico’s drug cartels is the backdrop for Teodora Ana Mihai’s first dramatic feature.

results.title: ‘The Forger’ Review: Hiding in Plain Sight
results.abstract: This German drama follows a young Jewish man in early 1940s Berlin who survives by falsifying passports and concealing his identity in public.

results.title: ‘Split at the Root’ Review: A Powerful Lens on Immigrant Families Split Apart
results.abstract: This documentary shows the plight of one woman as she tries to reunite with her sons and make a permanent home in the United States.

results.title: ‘Sansón and Me’ Review: Retracing a Path to Prison
results.abstract: The filmmaker Rodrigo Reyes examines immigration and incarceration through the story of a young undocumented man caught up in gang violence.

results.title: When Clothes Fly Off, This Intimacy Coordinator Steps In
results.abstract: Jessica Steinrock’s work on intimate scenes in film has come to prominence as the entertainment industry reels from the litany of sexual abuses brought to light by the #MeToo movement.

multimedia.caption: Jessica Steinrock, the chief executive of Intimacy Directors and Coordinators, is at the vanguard of a field that facilitates the production of scenes involving nudity, simulated sex or hyper exposure.

results.title: Richard Anobile, Chronicler of the Marx Brothers, Dies at 76
results.abstract: He produced many books about film. But Groucho Marx tried to stop distribution of one collaborative effort because he didn’t like seeing his salty and insulting remarks in print.

multimedia.caption: The film critic Roger Ebert called “The Marx Bros. Scrapbook” “the all-time definitive work on the subject.”
The film critic Roger Ebert called “The Marx Bros. Scrapbook” “the all-time definitive work on the subject.”

results.title: Andie MacDowell Is Still Scaling New Heights
results.abstract: The star of the movie “My Happy Ending” gets a boost from Sam Harris and bell hooks audiobooks, the music of the 1970s and the quiet intelligence of “EO.”

multimedia.caption: In “My Happy Ending,” Andie MacDowell plays an actress fighting cancer while attempting a comeback. “I wanted to make her real: someone who’s struggling with her career but also has a sense of humor about it,” she said.
multimedia.copyright: Mike Coppola/Getty Images For Hallmark Media

results.title: Tom Luddy, a Behind-the-Scenes Force in Cinema, Dies at 79
results.abstract: Known for his association with Francis Ford Coppola, Werner Herzog and many others, he was also a founder of the Telluride Film Festival.
org_facet: Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive

multimedia.caption: Tom Luddy in 2004 at the Telluride Film Festival in Colorado, which he helped found. The filmmaker Paul Schrader called him “the big bang of film consciousness.”
multimedia.copyright: John Fago, via Telluride Film Festival

results.title: French Documentary ‘On the Adamant’ Wins Top Prize at Berlin Film Festival
results.abstract: Christian Petzold’s “Afire” took the runner-up award at this year’s Berlinale, where geopolitical crises in Europe and Iran loomed large.

multimedia.caption: Nicolas Philibert directed the documentary “On the Adamant,” which won the Golden Bear, the Berlin International Film Festival’s highest honor, on Saturday.

results.title: In the Wild Tale of ‘Cocaine Bear,’ an Apex Predator Is the True Star
results.abstract: The horror-comedy is based on a real story from 1985, but the director Elizabeth Banks and writer Jimmy Warden gave their furry lead a different ending.

results.title: Ricardo Darín: Argentina’s Lucky Charm at the Oscars
results.abstract: When the country has a nominated film, it has usually starred this veteran. But the actor says other people have believed in his talent more than he has.

multimedia.caption: A working actor since he was a child, Ricardo Darín said, “I often think, ‘Do I deserve all that?’”

results.title: In ‘The Quiet Girl,’ an Irish Loneliness Rarely Seen Onscreen
results.abstract: The first Irish-language film to be nominated for an Oscar, directed by Colm Bairéad, tells a gentle story of cultural reticence.

multimedia.caption: In “The Quiet Girl,” Catherine Clinch plays Cáit, who is shuttled from her chaotic family home to live with relatives for the summer.
In “The Quiet Girl,” Catherine Clinch plays Cáit, who is shuttled from her chaotic family home to live with relatives for the summer.
